newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL interbank rates steady as market remains tight.
newsitem.headline: KL interbank rates steady as market remains tight.

text.p: Interbank rates remained steady after recent gains as the market continued to be short of funds, dealers said on Thursday.
They said lack of any fresh liquidity inflows was expected to keep the interbank market tight until late next week.

Many dealers said they were waiting to see if Bank Negara would roll over a 500-million ringgit Bank Negara bill maturing next Wednesday. The central bank announces new issues of the bills ahead of the weekend.
The Malaysian money market is closed on Friday for the Moslem Eid al-Adha celebrations.
"Apart from the maturity, there is no new factor to change the market's trend," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
One-week money was at 7.80/90 percent, two-week was at 7.50/60 percent and three-week at 7.35/40 percent, all unchanged from Wednesday.
One-month to one-year were all trading between 7.35 and 7.45 percent, the dealers said.
The market tightened on Wednesday after an outflow of 500 million ringgit due to a Bank Negara bill.
The outflow coupled with a steady draining of foreign funds from Malaysia had tightened the market and pushed up rates, dealers said.
Dealers said there was market talk that foreign funds were withdrawing from Malaysia, both from deposits and from the stock market, which has been falling sharply recently.
Last week, Bank Negara intervened to slow the ringgit's fall by selling nearly $200 million, dealers said. A 500-million ringgit Bank Negara bill issue also reduced liquidity in the flush market.
Some dealers said there was also a persistent rumour about a possible long-term government bond issue soon, which would mop up further liquidity and roll over maturing bonds.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were steady across the board just ahead of the lunch break.
At 0420 GMT, three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate-based (KLIBOR) June contract was steady at 92.68, or an implied yield of 7.32 percent.
September was at 92.67, or 7.33 percent and December was down one point at 92.60, or 7.40 percent.
March 1998 contract was up one at 92.50.
